<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of atomic:
```c
static int atomic(void)
{
	const int threads = 10;
	atomic_int counter = ATOMIC_VAR_INIT(0);
	int value, error;

	error = metal_run(threads, atomic_thread, &counter);
	if (!error) {
		value = atomic_load(&counter);
		value -= atomic_test_count * threads;
		if (value) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "counter mismatch, delta = %d\n",
				  value);
			error = -EINVAL;
		}
	}

	return error;
}
```
</target_code>

int metal_run(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg)
{
	pthread_t tids[threads];
	int error, ts_created;

	error = metal_run_noblock(threads, child, arg, tids, &ts_created);

	metal_finish_threads(ts_created, (void *)tids);

	return error;
}
...
int metal_run_noblock(int threads, metal_thread_t child,
		     void *arg, void *tids, int *threads_out)
{
	int error, i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}

	error = 0;
	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++) {
		error = -pthread_create(&tid_p[i], NULL, child, arg);
		if (error) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to create thread - %s\n",
				  strerror(error));
			break;
		}
	}

	*threads_out = i;
	return error;
}
...
void metal_finish_threads(int threads, void *tids)
{
	int i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return;
	}

	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++)
		(void)pthread_join(tid_p[i], NULL);
}

</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The for loop is well-formed: the first clause (i = 0) initializes the single loop counter i; the second clause (i < threads) uses only the loop counter and the function parameter threads (which is not modified by the loop body); the third clause (i++) modifies only the loop counter. Objects that are modified in the loop body (tid_p[i] and error) are not used in the loop-controlling expressions. Therefore Rule 14.2 is not violated.
